text: The surface layer of soil we see is the organic horizon detritus, such as shreds of leaves fallen from plants.
The detritus of the organic horizon is in the earliest stages of decomposition by microbes, primarily fungi and bacteria such as actinomycetes.
Note that the soils of different habitats, such as prairie, forest, and desert, vary greatly as to the depth and quality of each layer.
Between the soil particles are air spaces that provide access to oxygen, allowing aerobic respiration.
Each particle of soil supports miniature colonies, biofilms, and filaments of bacteria and fungi that interact with each other and with the roots of plants (Fig. 21.33).
In well-drained soil, both the organic and aerated horizons are full of oxygen, as well as nutrients liberated by the decomposers and used by plants.
Early-stage decomposition is defined loosely as a state in which the origin of the detritus may be still recognizable.

In the aerated horizon, the source of the organic particles is no longer recognizable, and decomposers have broken down some of the more difficult-to-digest plant structural components, such as lignin (a complex aromatic polymer found in wood; discussed in the next section).
Beneath the organic horizon lies the lighter-colored more advanced stages of decomposition combine with minerals from rock at lower levels.
This partly decomposed material is often sold by garden stores as peat or topsoil.
Soil consists of a complex assemblage of organic and inorganic particles (Fig. 21.32).
21.32) includes a series of layers called “horizons” that arise as a result of soil-forming factors such as rainfall, temperature variation, wind, and biological activity.
